thread.title: EZSTAX dividers used to pack clothing in a carry-on suitcase
thread.title_full: EZSTAX dividers used to pack clothing in a carry-on suitcase | Daily Mail Online

author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: EZSTAX dividers used to pack clothing in a carry-on suitcase
text:
33 shares 18
View
comments
A Florida-based start-up company has raised more than $100,000 in a crowdfunding campaign to mass produce a product designed to keep travellers’ suitcases organised.
The EZSTAX interlocking dividers are primarily intended for organising closets and office drawers but they can also be used to neatly sort and stack clothing in a piece of hand luggage.
When a shirt is pulled from the middle or bottom the dividers lock, meaning travellers won’t make a mess or be forced to refold.
EZSTAX dividers are designed to organise everything from suitcases and closets to office drawers
Sarasota-based EZSTAX raised just under $120,000 (£78,500) from 1,598 backers when it launched a Kickstarter campaign over the summer.
 Guinness Storehouse in Ireland beats off competition from... Terrifying drone footage shows hiker swept down Hawaiian... It sought pledges of $20 (£13) in exchange for a stack of 20 trays, and is planning to deliver the plastic dividers to its backers in late September or early October.
Travellers won't make a mess when a divider is pulled from the middle or bottom, the company claims
The plastic dividers come in two sizes - regular and small - and can fit inside standard carry-on suitcases
With the ability to hold one piece of clothing in each slot, the dividers are manufactured in the US and made from rPET plastic, which is made from 100 per cent recycled materials, the company said.
They come in two different sizes – regular and small – with EZSTAX saying they fit comfortably inside carry-on suitcases that are standard in the US and Europe.
Regular folders are approximately 13.5in deep by 11.5in wide and 2in high, while small folders are approximately 12in deep by 9in wide and 2in high.
